column1: Interstitial keratitis is inflammation of the tissue of the cornea, the clear window on the front of the eye.
Interstitial keratitis is a serious condition in which blood vessels grow into the cornea.

Syphilis is the most common cause of interstitial keratitis, but rare causes include: - Autoimmune diseases, like rheumatoid arthritis and sarcoidosis - Leprosy - Lyme disease - Tuberculosis In the United States, most cases of syphilis are recognized and treated before this eye condition develops.
However, interstitial keratitis remains the most common cause of blindness in the world.
Interstitial keratitis can be easily diagnosed by slit-lamp examination of the eyes.
Blood tests and chest x-rays will usually be needed to confirm the infection or disease that is causing the condition.
A corneal transplant is not as successful for interstitial keratitis as it is for most other corneal diseases.
All people with interstitial keratitis will be closely followed by an ophthalmologist and a medical specialist with expertise in the underlying disease.
Prevention consists of avoiding the infection that causes interstitial keratitis.
